text:
Top 10 autumnal to-do on the Wild Atlantic Way Published on : Friday, October 9, 2015
1. Catch a wave
Head to the Surf Coast, which stretches from Donegal to Erris, and get on board for an adrenalin- charged surfing experience. The Atlantic delivers both gentle ripples and monster slabs to guarantee an exhilarating rush for beginners and skilled waveriders alike.
2. Walk on the wild side
Take a (literally) breath-taking cliff top walk around Loop Head peninsula, taking in wildlife, history, geology, heritage, scenery and of course the obligatory stops to chat with the locals and enjoy a meal or a coffee. Enjoy lighthouses, spectacular Atlantic views and the chance to spot a dolphin at this European Destination of Excellence.
3. Have fun at a festival
Beat a path to Sligo Live, Ireland’s premier folk, roots and indie music festival, which takes place 21-26 October. All performances are indoors in venues across the beautiful town of Sligo, so you can enjoy the full festival programme without the risk of getting wet. (Sometimes it rains in Ireland.)
4. Tee off in the Northern Headlands
Sign up for a golfing package that spans six of the best courses along the Wild Atlantic Way together with top-class hotel accommodation. Tee off at Ballyliffn Golf Club, then play other courses in County Donegal, County Sligo and County Mayo, finishing up in the rugged environs of the Twelve Bens Mountains at Connemara Golf Links near Clifden.
5. Cycle the Great Western Greenway
Saddle up for a superlative cycling experience along the 42km traffic-free Great Western Greenway, which passes by some of Ireland’s most striking landscapes including Nephin Mountains, island-studded Clew Bay and Croagh Patrick – Ireland’s ‘holiest’ mountain.
6. Tempt your taste buds
Indulge in a Galway gourmet tour —Around the Market Place. Featuring the city’s finest foodie destinations, it’s a chance to meet artisan producers and sample their products while soaking up the unique atmosphere of this vibrant city. Enjoy the finest cheese, the freshest oysters, hoppy beer, flavoursome coffee and the sweetest treats.
7. Wonder at the Skellig Experience
Discover the unique story of the Skellig Islands at the state-of-the-art Skellig Experience Visitor Centre in County Kerry, which reveals the history and archaeology of Skellig Michael’s Early Christian monastery, now a World Heritage Site. The centre also has three other exhibitions— The Sea Birds, The Lighthouses and Underwater Skellig.
8. Take a music tour
Immerse yourself in the music of Ireland with an Irish Music Tour in County Donegal in the company of talented musicians. Weekend or week-long tours combine visits to the makers of uilleann pipes, bodhráns, harps, flutes and banjos with evening sessions in pubs along the way.
9. Relax on a yoga retreat
Take turns to relax and go wild in this unique 8-day experience. Each day begins with a yoga session, afternoons are given over to walking and cycling, whale-watching and kayaking and evenings to tasting local food, dancing at ceilís, storytelling and traditional music sessions.
10. Enjoy a pint and some pub theatre
For a chill autumn night’s entertainment with a twist, head to John B. Keane’s Pub in Listowel, County Kerry. Keane was a famous playwright and the pub, now run by his son, features Pub Theatre in the form of 40-minute plays. Keane’s also offers visitors the chance to try their hand at pulling a perfect pint of Guinness.
